subject: Gardening
title: Texture as a Design Element
description: A 60-second lesson on Texture as a Design Element.

hook.text: A garden of all fine-textured plants looks flat. Add one bold-leaved plant and suddenly depth appears.

buildup.text: Texture in gardens ranges from fine (grasses, fennel) to coarse (hostas, gunnera). Mixing textures creates visual depth.

discovery.text: Fine textures recede visuallyâ€”making spaces look larger. Coarse textures advanceâ€”making spaces feel more intimate.

twist.text: Texture outranks color in winter. When flowers vanish, bark, stems, and evergreen foliage carry the design.

climax.text: Great designers think in textures year-round. Color is seasonal; texture is permanent structure.

punchline.text: Color fades in winter. Texture carries the garden.

quiz.question: How do fine and coarse textures affect the perception of garden space?
options: Fine textures make spaces feel smaller while coarse textures expand them
Fine textures recede (enlarging space) while coarse textures advance (creating intimacy)
Both textures have the same visual effect on garden space
